profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Monday April 29, 2019 at 21:01

repository.corpname: Yale Center for British Art, Rare Books and Manuscripts

did.abstract: The collection comprises correspondence, notebooks, writings, and other manuscript material by or about the artist Joshua Reynolds.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Joshua Reynolds Archive, Yale Center for British Art, Gift of Frederick W. Hilles.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Letters by Reynolds have been published by Hilles and Ingamells/Edgcumbe, as noted in the Bibliography herewith. Material in the present collection described in Ingamells has been annotated with the Ingamells entry number.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The collection is the physical property of the Yale Center for British Art. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the Curator of Rare Books and Manuscripts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into four series: I. Correspondence; II. Commonplace books, notebooks, and diaries; III. Writings; and IV. Miscellaneous.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional material from the Hilles collection of Reynolds material is now in the Department of Prints and Drawings at the Yale Center for British Art. Records for this material may be accessed in the YCBA's online catalog: http://http://britishart.yale.edu/collections/search

A portion of the Hilles collection of Reynolds material is now at the Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library (Yale University), in the Frederick W. Hilles Manuscript Collection http://hdl.handle.net/10079/fa/beinecke.hilles.

Frederick W. Hilles' copy of his Letters of Sir Joshua Reynolds (Cambridge, 1929), with his profuse annotations, is now in the collections of the Yale Center for British Art: http://hdl.handle.net/10079/bibid/582640.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: "There has never been a time when Joshua Reynolds was not regarded as one of the great men of the Enlightenment in England and a portrait and history painter of tremendous versatility, inventiveness, originality, and ambition.

Reynolds was the seventh of the ten or eleven children of a schoolmaster and his wife, both of whose families were abundant with Church of England clergymen. Showing prodigious talent as a boy, he was apprenticed for four years to the London portrait painter Thomas Hudson of Lincoln's Inn Fields, before establishing a burgeoning portrait practice in London and Plymouth. In 1749-50, Reynolds traveled to Italy and France by way of Spain and Morocco. In Rome he copied the Old Masters, for eighteen months scouring the city's churches' princely art collections and working his way back across the Continent, similarly absorbing a host of artistic exempla. Upon his return to London, Reynolds resumed his portrait practice and achieved rapid commercial and critical success, although the failure of some of his experiments with certain fugitive pigments and varnishes was soon apparent.

Beginning in 1760, when he leased a large house at 47 Leicester Square, Reynolds exhibited with the Society of Artists but eventually distanced himself from the squabbles that increasingly divided the members from their committee. He also hesitated before accepting the invitation to become the first President of a rival "Academy" that was founded in 1768 with patronage of King George III. As President, Reynolds was knighted in April 1769, an honor that was not without precedent but that signaled Reynolds's certain preeminence in the institutional art world of London. In the Discourses he delivered as President, Reynolds set out the principles to which a great national school of art should adhere, ennobled by poetry and eloquence, intellectual dignity, and the purity of the so-called great style of Michelangelo, Raphael, and the Florentine-Roman tradition of disegno.

In the 1770s and 1780s, Reynolds's portrait subjects included most of the great men and women of the age: his own good friend Dr. Samuel Johnson, the king and queen, Sir Joseph Banks, James Boswell, Oliver Goldsmith, David Garrick, and others. He created a sideline in imaginative portrait studies of children, known as "fancy pictures," and also experimented with history painting. As Reynolds aged, he showed an increasing awareness of and interest in Dutch art and continued to be showered with honors, both domestic and foreign. In old age, the deafness he blamed on a chill he said he caught in the Sistine Chapel got worse (but that, like his harelip, was probably hereditary); in addition, his eyesight deteriorated. Although he was immensely self-important, and to that extent personally vain, in his marvelous self-portraits Reynolds freely acknowledged the existence of all three maladies, most obviously the harelip, but also his ear trumpet and spectacles, while other artists in their portraits of him rarely acknowledged their existence. After his death in 1792, Reynolds's body was attended by ten pallbearers, among whom were three dukes, two marquesses, three earls, and a cortègee of ninety-one carriages."--Paul Mellon's Legacy (2007).

Frederick Whiley Hilles (1900-1975) was a longtime professor of English at Yale University and editor of works on Samuel Johnson, James Boswell, and Joshua Reynolds. Hilles collected correspondence and other manuscript writings by James Boswell, Thomas Carlyle, Samuel Johnson, Joshua Reynolds, and members of their families. Most of this material is now at the Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library (Yale University), in the Frederick W. Hilles Manuscript Collection (http://hdl.handle.net/10079/fa/beinecke.hilles). Hilles's Reynolds collection was featured (along with material from other collections) in An exhibition of books, manuscripts & prints pertaining to Sir Joshua Reynolds, on the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of his birth (Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library, 1973). A portion of Hilles's Reynolds material now forms the present collection at the Yale Center for British Art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection comprises correspondence, notebooks, writings, and other manuscript material by or about the artist Joshua Reynolds. Correspondents include Francis Barton Abington, Carl Fredrik Adelcrantz, John Bacon, Joseph Banks, Edmund Burke, Sir William Hamilton, John Hely-Hutchinson, Henry Hope, Hendrik Jansen, Samuel Johnson, William Johnson, Bennet Langton, Elizabeth Montagu, Thomas Percy, William Roscoe, Charles Manners, Duke of Rutland, Richard Brinsley Sheridan, F.G. Waldron, Benjamin West, and Pieter Yver. Several of the notebooks record Reynolds's travels on the Continent, with notes on paintings seen in France, Germany, and the Low Countries. Among the writings are Reynolds's thoughts on blindness, fragments of his Discourses, and notes on Pliny and Johnson. Some of the material throughout the collection concerns Reynolds's tenure as the first president of the Royal Academy.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Reynolds, Joshua. Letters of Sir Joshua Reynolds collected and edited by Frederick Whiley Hilles. Cambridge (England) : University Press, 1929.
Reynolds, Joshua. The letters of Sir Joshua Reynolds , edited by John Ingamells and John Edgcumbe. New Haven: Yale University Press for the Paul Mellon Centre for Studies in British Art, 2000.
Wendorf, Richard. Sir Joshua Reynolds: the painter in society. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 1996
Yale University Library. An exhibition of books, manuscripts & prints pertaining to Sir Joshua Reynolds. New Haven : Yale University Library, 1973.

Reynolds, Joshua, Sir, 1723-1792 -- Notebooks, sketchbooks, etc.
Rutland, Charles Manners, Duke of, 1754-1787 -- Correspondence
Upper Ossory, Anne Fitzpatrick, Countess of, 1737 or 8-1804 -- Correspondence
Upper Ossory, John Fitzpatrick, Earl of, 1745-1818

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from Port Mahon, Minorca. Concerning his voyage to Italy. Ingamells no. 5.

unittitle.emph: Letter to the Honorable William Hamilton at Naples

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Regarding the establishment of the Royal Academy, of which Sir Joshua Reynolds has the honor of being president. Ingamells no. 21.

unittitle.emph: Letter to Frances Abington at Pallmall

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Accepting an invitation. Ingamells no. 231.

unittitle.emph: Letter to Sir Joshua Reynolds and his nieces

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from Hill Street. Dinner invitation for 7 January 1777.

unittitle.emph: Letter to the Reverend Thomas Percy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Requesting Thomas Percy's aid on behalf of a relative of Jane [Mrs. Edmund] Burke. Ingamells no. 60.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Addressed to the Secretary of State in Ireland. Letter of recommendation for a young painter, William Doughty, a pupil of Reynolds, who wishes to spend a few months in Ireland. Ingamells no. 90.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sending him, presumably, his lives of Denham, Butler, and Waller, specially bound to be read by friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Apologizing to his nephew for his tardiness in writing, and wishing him success in India. Ingamells no. 91.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from Rotterdam. Includes impression of paintings by Rubens, with description of Rotterdam and surrounding countryside. Ingamells no. 95.

unittitle.emph: Letter to Sir Joshua Reynolds at London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from Amsterdam. An agent in Amsterdam, Yver, reports to Sir Joshua Reynolds on certain paintings he has purchased for him. Signed Pierre Yver.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from Amsterdam. Concerning the shipping of pictures purchased for Sir Joshua Reynolds by Pieter Yver.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from London. Introducing the young artist, Mr. Meyer, and mentioning the "violent inflammation in his [own] eye." Notes Miss Theophila Palmer's marriage to Robert Gwatkin. Ingamells no. 108.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for Mason's translation of du Fresnoy and sending him the new edition of his The Lives of the Poets , just published. A presentation inscription from R. B. Adam, a former owner, to R. W. Chapman is written on the mount surrounding the letter. A copy of the pamphlet by R. W. Chapman, entitled The lives of the poets: Sir Joshua Reynolds's copy of the first edition, sent to him by Johnson 19 February 1783 , 1929, is affixed to the back of the mount. Another copy of the pamphlet is affixed to the case. With the letter is cased: Gwatkin, R. G. ALS to R. W. Chapman. Oxford, January 13 [1930?].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hoping to promote Joseph Palmer, Sir Joshua Reynolds' nephew. Congratulating Sir Joshua on his new appointment as principal painter to the King.

controlaccess.persname: Rutland, Charles Manners, Duke of, 1754-1787 -- Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Referring to the portrait of Colonel Tarleton. Ingamells no. 127.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from London. Concerning two paintings by Rubens which Reynolds wishes to buy. Addressed to "Monsieur Cunynham, at Lille." Ingamells no. 146. Ingamells identifies the recipient as possibly William Burton Conyngham (1733-1796); previously identified as Edmund Francis Cunningham.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from Leicester Fields. Concerning a picture of Milton. "Sir Joshua Reynolds presents his compliments to Mr. Waldron..." Ingamells no. 145.

unittitle.emph: Letter to the Earl of Upper Ossory

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from London. Offering to trade Gainsborough's "Girl with Pigs" for a damaged "Venus and Adonis" copied by Titian. Ingamells no. 153.

controlaccess.persname: Upper Ossory, John Fitzpatrick, Earl of, 1745-1818 -- Correspondence

unittitle.emph: Letter to Sir George Beaumont at Tunbridge Wells

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from London. Hastily telling him of paintings to see while in the Low Countries. Ingamells no. 156.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from London. Sending Jansen "all the Discourses since the year 1776." Expressing his appreciation for Jansen's translation of his Discourses into French. Ingamells no. 161.
On same sheet as Reynolds 20b: Jansen's letter to Reynolds from Paris, October 10, 1786.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: First draft (?) of Jansen's response to Reynolds' letter of October 2, 1786. Written on same sheet as Reynolds 20a.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sending him a copy of the thirteenth Discourse , just published. Jansen was translating the Discourses into French. Ingamells no. 167.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sending him a present in pottles for the Langton children. Ingamells no. 174.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Offering condolences on the death of Palmer's patron, the Duke of Rutland, and giving further advice on the subject of patrons. Ingamells no. 179.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Presenting to him the portrait of Mrs. Sheridan as St. Cecilia, "the best picture I ever painted." Ingamells no. 191.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from Frampton Court, Dorchester. Presenting the letter written by Sir Joshua Reynolds to Richard Brinsley Sheridan, January 20, 1790.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A note concerning the quarrel that led to Sir Joshua Reynolds' resignation from the Royal Academy. Ingamells no. 192.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from Leicester Fields. A brief note accompanying Boswell's letter of the day before, mentioning his failing eyesight. Verso: Clipping of a short biography of Reynolds. With a stipple engraving of Reynolds by H. Meyer, after M. Haughton (from the original painted by Reynolds himself). Ingamells no. 198.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Offering to send his coach if West wishes to accompany him to see the drawings in the collection of Mr. Hankey. Ingamells no. 200.
Verso: graphite sketch by West (23 x 26 cm).

unittitle.emph: Letter to the Countess of Ossory

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter of thanks for the hand-embroidered waistcoat. Ingamells no. 211.

controlaccess.subject: Clothing and dress
controlaccess.persname: Upper Ossory, Anne Fitzpatrick, Countess of, 1737 or 8-1804 -- Correspondence

unittitle.emph: Letter to Sir Joseph Banks, Bart

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Asking him as chairman of the committee to call a meeting concerning the monument to be erected to Dr. Johnson. Ingamells no. 215.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from Stockholm. Requesting that de Breda, now in London, be permitted to paint for the Swedish Academy a portrait of Sir Joshua Reynolds, "the most celebrated artist of this century."

did.unittitle: Commonplace book: given to young Reynolds by his father

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains records copied from the family Bible and quotations from his reading. The latest date in the book is a year after Reynolds went to London to study under Thomas Hudson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains extracts from his reading (chiefly Pope and Shakespeare) and rough drafts of projected essays on painting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lists people and houses to be seen in Paris, and pictures that he examined, chiefly those at the Hotel de Thiers that Catherine the Great was about to buy.
This notebook is the subject of: Frederick W. Hilles, "Sir Joshua and the Hotel de Thiers," Gazette des beaux-arts (Oct. 1969): 201-210.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brief notes made on his first trip to Brussels. Also on microfilm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notes on paintings seen in Antwerp. In a pocket are business cards issued by picture dealers. Cased with Reynolds 38.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inscribed: "A Painter's Journal through Flanders, Brabant, Holland, and part of Germany. June 24, 1781." Cased with Reynolds 37.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brief notes on pictures at St. Omers, Lisle, Tournay, Brussels, Mecklin, and Calais.

unittitle.emph: Sketchbook formerly attributed to Sir Joshua Reynolds

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sketchbook including sketches once believed to be in preparation for Mrs. Siddons as Tragic Muse .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A description in Reynolds' hand of his sensations when his sight was impaired. Including two newsprint biographies of the artist and handwritten notation: "Autograph of Sir Joshua Reynolds---of J. Waller Fleet St 1876."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Scraps rescued from trash by Sir Joshua's pupil James Northcote, who later became his biographer. Including several handwritten notations by James Northcote verifying the hand of Sir Joshua Reynolds. With this is cased Manuscript Fragments of Discourses and Lecture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Including one notation by Northcote which verifies the hand of Reynolds. Cased with Manuscript Fragments of Discourses .

unittitle.emph: Draft dedication for Art of painting

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft of a never-completed dedication to William Mason of a new edition of du Fresnoy's Art of painting , a Latin poem translated by Mason and annotated by Reynolds (published by A. Ward, 1783).

unittitle.emph: Draft on Reynolds' collection of Old Masters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rough draft of a portion of catalogue for Reynolds' exhibition of his collection of Old Masters in the spring of 1791. [Appears to be a draft for a paragraph which was published in the Morning Chronicle , Fri., April 22, 1791.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notes on Melmoth's translation of Pliny's letters, made in 1750 on the trip to Italy.

unittitle.emph: Notes on Johnson's Lives of the poets

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notes on Johnson's Lives of the Poets , made after Johnson's death, and used when Reynolds was revising his Discourses for the collected edition. Discovered with Boswell Papers in a stable loft at Malahide Castle.

unittitle.emph: Receipt for portraits of the Marquis of Granby

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A reply in verse to a remark made by Johnson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Offering criticism on the writings of Frances Reynolds (sister of Joshua Reynolds).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Complaining of illness and solitude, and speaking of the comfort of having Frances Reynolds near. Mounted verso: "I have the honour to be/Sir/Your most Obedient and/most humble Servant/Howe."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dinner invitation.

unittitle.emph: Letters to William Johnson, in India

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series of bound letters; including handwritten descriptions of these twenty five letters by a relative of Mary Palmer (sister of Sir Joshua Reynolds), and typewritten description of the same on letterhead of Hamill & Barker, 230 North Michigan Ave., Chicago.

unittitle.emph: Heights of members of the Royal Academy Club

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The list includes the names of 28 club members, but heights are recorded for five only: Reynolds, Sir William Chambers, John Singleton Copley, John Webber, and Ozias Humphry.

unittitle.emph: Letter (initialed "CB") to Miss Burney, at Queen's House

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter written to his daughter, Frances, after hearing Sir Joshua Reynolds deliver his final Discourse at the Royal Academy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Obituary written in JR's home immediately following his death. Typewritten transcription included.

unittitle.emph: Copy of speech delivered to the Royal Academy, 28 February 1792

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Speech delivered to the Royal Academy at a special meeting held after Reynolds' death.

unittitle.emph: Letter to Mrs. Johnson, at Torrington, Devon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written in London. Requesting personal information and important dates in the life of their brother, Sir Joshua Reynolds, on behalf of the biographer, Edmund Malone. With this is bound Elizabeth Johnson's letter to Frances Reynolds, 4 December 1796.

unittitle.emph: Letter to Edward (!sic) Malone Esq. at Queen Anne Street East

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inviting Edmund Malone to call in order that he might ask further questions concerning the biography of Sir Joshua Reynolds. Cased with Frances Reynolds' letter to Mrs. Johnson, at Torrington, Devon and Elizabeth Johnson's letter to Frances Reynolds.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Apparently the text or first draft of a response to her sister. Additional script in same hand exists at bottom of sheet and is dated 15 December. Bound with Frances Reynolds' letter to Mrs. Johnson, at Torrington, Devon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Verses entitled "Merry and Wise" written when Beauclerk forgot an invitation he had extended to Reynolds, Barnard, and Garrick, probably in 1775.

unittitle.emph: Manuscript copy of "Lettera scritta da Giuseppe Baretti a Luigi Siries a Firenze"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Giuseppe Pelli's copy of Baretti's printed pamphlet Baretti critical of Siries [see Reynolds 60, below].

unittitle.emph: "Lettera scritta da Giuseppe Baretti a Luigi Siries a Firenze"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this privately printed pamphlet Baretti criticizes Siries for editing and publishing Baretti's translation of the first seven of Sir Joshua Reynolds' Discourses (Delle arti del disegno. Firenze, 1778) without mentioning Baretti's name in the publication, and for altering the text. Distributed gratis throughout Italy, particularly in Tuscany (cf. Hilles, p. 54). Discussion of this pamphlet and an English translation appear in Hilles, F.W. Literary career of Sir Joshua Reynolds (1936 ed.), p. 51-59. This copy is addressed in manuscript (and was evidently mailed to) Giuseppe Pelli, director of the Royal Art Gallery in Florence.

did.unittitle: Johnson and Garrick: (Not Published). London, Printed by Nichols, Son, and Bentley...1816

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "The following jeu d'esprit was written by Sir Joshua Reynolds to illustrate a remark which he made, 'That Dr. Johnson considered Garrick as his property, and would suffer anyone to praise or abuse him but himself.' In the first of these supposed dialogues, Sir Joshua himself, by high encomiums upon Garrick, is represented as drawing down upon him Johnson's censure; in the second, Mr. Gibbon, by taking the opposite side, calls forth his praise."--Title page verso.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning the unpublished "Johnson and Garrick" written by Sir Joshua Reynolds. Cased with "Johnson and Garrick."

unittitle.emph: Invitation to Sir Joshua Reynolds' funeral at the Royal Academy
Letter to Edmund Burke, Edmund Malone, and Philip Metcalfe

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from Curzon Street. Declining the invitation to Sir Joshua Reynolds' funeral.

unittitle.emph: Letter to Sir Joshua Reynolds, at Leicester Square

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written from Whitton Place. Concerning Sir William Chalmers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Complaining about expensive presents offered by Sir William Hamilton to the Royal Academy.

unittitle.emph: Collection of autograph drafts concerning his own collection of pictures
Notes on the life of Sir Joshua Reynolds, containing an excerpt from a narrative by Anthony Pascin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Creator unidentified.
